slides.subtitle: An Introduction to the Language of the Web

list.text: Variables & Data Types - Storing and using data
Control Flow - Making decisions in your code
The language of the web - Runs in all modern browsers
Versatile - Used for frontend, backend, mobile, and more
Dynamic - No need to specify data types
1995 - Created by Brendan Eich at Netscape
2009 - Node.js allows JavaScript to run on servers
Null & Undefined: typeof null is object, typeof undefined is undefined
var: Function-scoped, can be re-declared and re-assigned. Hoisted with a default value of undefined.
let: Block-scoped, can be re-assigned but not re-declared. Hoisted but not initialized (Temporal Dead Zone).
const: Block-scoped, cannot be re-assigned or re-declared. Must be initialized at declaration. For objects/arrays, the reference is constant, but contents can be modified.
Primitives: Stored directly in the location that the variable accesses. (String, Number, Boolean, Null, Undefined, Symbol, BigInt). Passed by value.
Non-Primitives (Objects): Stored as a reference to a memory location. (Objects, Arrays, Functions). Passed by reference.

box.content: JavaScript often automatically converts values from one type to another (type coercion).
box.code:
// Implicit Coercion
console.log('5' + 5); // '55' (Number to String)
console.log('5' - 5); // 0 (String to Number)
console.log(true + 1); // 2 (Boolean to Number)

// Explicit Coercion
console.log(Number('10')); // 10
console.log(String(100)); // '100'
console.log(Boolean(0)); // false

let x = 10;
let y = 5;

console.log(x + y); // 15
console.log(x - y); // 5
console.log(x * y); // 50
console.log(x / y); // 2
console.log(x % y); // 0
console.log(x ** y); // 100000

// Comparison
console.log(10 == "10"); // true (loose equality)
console.log(10 === "10"); // false (strict equality)
console.log(10 != "10"); // false
console.log(10 !== "10"); // true
console.log(10 > 5); // true

// Logical
console.log(true && false); // false
console.log(true || false); // true
console.log(!true); // false

let x = 10;
x += 5; // x is now 15 (x = x + 5)
x -= 3; // x is now 12 (x = x - 3)
x *= 2; // x is now 24 (x = x * 2)
x /= 4; // x is now 6 (x = x / 4)
x %= 5; // x is now 1 (x = x % 5)

box.content: Determines the order in which operators are evaluated.
box.code:
let result = 5 + 3 * 2; // result is 11 (multiplication before addition)
let result2 = (5 + 3) * 2; // result2 is 16 (parentheses change precedence)

fetch("https://api.example.com/data")
  .then(response => response.json())
  .then(data => console.log(data))
  .catch(error => console.error(error));
